friend.translation[0].definitions[0].def: someone who you know and like very much and enjoy spending time with
friend.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: Jerry, this is my friend Sue.
She’s always out with her friends.
One of her closest friends died at the weekend.
I met Jim through a friend.
friend.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: Jenny has always found it easy to make friends at school.
friend.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: He made friends with an old fisherman.
friend.translation[0].definitions[3].def: someone who supports an organization such as a theatre, art gallery, charity etc by giving money or help
friend.translation[0].definitions[4].def: someone who has the same beliefs, wants to achieve the same things etc as you, and will support you
friend.translation[0].definitions[4].exa: our friends and allies around the world
She shot him a quick glance as if unsure whether he was friend or foe.
friend.translation[0].definitions[5].def: someone who has created a link with you on a social networking site on the Internet, by visiting your webpage and clicking on it
friend.translation[0].definitions[5].exa: She has thousands of friends on MySpace.
friend.translation[0].definitions[6].def: used by a member of parliament when speaking about another member of parliament
friend.translation[0].definitions[7].def: used by a lawyer when speaking about another lawyer in a court of law
friend.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: She’s a good friend of mine.
I’d like you to meet a dear friend of mine.
We went to see some old friends who had moved to Harlow.
The two men were lifelong friends.
She had been a childhood friend of Tony Walker.
I met some old school friends for lunch.
Mr Hutton is a close personal friend of my father.
They went to a mutual friend’s home for dinner.
They had remained firm friends ever since they first met.
She told only a few trusted friends.
Most of my male friends are married now.
Liz and Vanessa soon became friends.
We have all remained friends despite some difficult times.
A friend of mine is going to Tokyo next week.
I managed to get tickets from a friend of a friend.
Her small circle of friends used to play cards together.
friend.translation[0].note_box[1].sectio: friend
someone who you know and like very much and enjoy spending time with
Dad, this is my friend Steve.
She’s going to Palm Springs with some friends.
I got a letter from a friend from college.
Amy’s a close friend of mine.
John was a really good friend to me when I had all those problems last year.
acquaintance
someone who you know and see sometimes, but who is not one of your close friends
We borrowed the money from one of Paul’s business acquaintances.
mate
a friend – used especially about boys or men
He always goes to the pub with his mates on Friday night.
Terry’s an old mate of mine.
buddy
a friend – used especially about men or young people
He’s out playing basketball with some of his high school buddies.
pal
a friend – pal sounds rather old-fashioned
They met at school and have remained close pals.
crony
a friend – used about powerful people who will help each other even if it is slightly dishonest
He’s one of the president’s cronies.
companion
someone who spends time with you, doing the same things as you – used about animals as well as people
travelling companions
His dog was his constant companion.
the perfect companion
the girls
a woman’s female friends
We’re having a girls’ night out.
the lads
a man’s male friends
a night out with the lads
friend.translation[1].definitions[0].def: a member of the Society of Friends
friend.translation[2].definitions[0].def: to add someone to your list of friends on a social networking site
friend.translation[2].definitions[0].exa: I never friend someone I haven’t met in real life.
friend.translation[3].definitions[0].def: a member of the Christian group called the Society of Friends; Quaker
